message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis of networked systems: progress, prospects and challenges
Paper Abstract: Copyright © 2021 The Author(s). In recent years, the communication-protocol-based synthesis and analysis issues have gained substantial research interest owing mainly to their significance in networked systems. In this work, we survey the control and filtering problems of networked systems under the effects induced by communication protocols. First, we introduce the engineering background of networked systems as well as the theoretical frameworks established to deal with the communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis problems. Then, recent advances (especially the latest results) are reviewed on the stability analysis issue subject to protocol scheduling. Subsequently, the particular effort is devoted to presenting the latest progress on various communication-protocol-based control and filtering problems according to the characteristics of networked systems (e.g. time-varying nature, random behaviours, types of parameter uncertainties, and kinds of distributed structure). After that, we provide a systematic review of the communication-protocol-based fault diagnosis problems. Finally, some research challenges of communication-protocol-based control and filtering problems are outlined for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Networked system"

Links: [{"title":"Networked control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system"},{"title":"Network Computing System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Computing_System"},{"title":"Network dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_dynamics"},{"title":"Network operating system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_operating_system"},{"title":"Computer network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network"},{"title":"International Conference on Formal Techniques for Networked and Distributed Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Formal_Techniques_for_Networked_and_Distributed_Systems"},{"title":"Node (networking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Node_(networking)"},{"title":"University of Pennsylvania - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singh_Program_in_Networked_&_Social_Systems_Engineering_(NETS)"},{"title":"Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symposium_on_Networked_Systems_Design_and_Implementation"},{"title":"Network information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_information_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about networked systems:

## Key Definitions

The term "networked system" can refer to several different concepts depending on context:

### Networked Control Systems
A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

### General Networked Systems
More broadly, networked systems are typically characterized as complex systems consisting of many units coupled by specific, potentially changing, interaction topologies.(no content)The networked systems could be from the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, sociology, economics, computer science, etc.

### Network Information Systems
A network information system (NIS) is an information system for managing networks, such as electricity network, water supply network, gas supply network, telecommunications network, or street light network.

## Challenges
For networked control systems specifically, the insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about networked systems:

## Key Definitions

The term "networked system" can refer to several different concepts depending on context:

### Networked Control Systems
A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

### General Networked Systems
More broadly, networked systems are typically characterized as complex systems consisting of many units coupled by specific, potentially changing, interaction topologies.(no content)The networked systems could be from the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, sociology, economics, computer science, etc.

### Network Information Systems
A network information system (NIS) is an information system for managing networks, such as electricity network, water supply network, gas supply network, telecommunications network, or street light network.

## Challenges
For networked control systems specifically, the insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Search Results for "Communication Protocol"

I've found comprehensive information about communication protocols. Here's what the search revealed:

### Definition and Basics

A communication protocol is a system of rules that allows two or more entities of a communications system to transmit information, defining the rules, syntax, semantics, and synchronization of communication and possible error recovery methods.(no content)Protocols may be implemented by hardware, software, or a combination of both.

### Key Characteristics

Communicating systems use well-defined formats for exchanging various messages, where each message has an exact meaning intended to elicit a response from a range of possible responses predetermined for that particular situation.

### Organization and Standards

A group of protocols designed to work together is known as a protocol suite; when implemented in software they are a protocol stack.(no content)Internet communication protocols are published by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), the IEEE handles wired and wireless networking, the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) handles other types, and the ITU-T handles telecommunications protocols.

### Historical Context

The best-known frameworks are the TCP/IP model and the OSI model.

The search results also include information about various specific protocols such as military communications protocols (SIMPLE), secure communications standards (SCIP), and transportation-related protocols (NTCIP), showing the wide range of applications for communication protocols across different industries.

Web search results for query: "Fault detection"

Links: [{"title":"Fault detection and isolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation"},{"title":"Arc-fault circuit interrupter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arc-fault_circuit_interrupter"},{"title":"Arc fault - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arc_fault"},{"title":"Earth-leakage circuit breaker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth-leakage_circuit_breaker"},{"title":"Therese Tucker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therese_Tucker"},{"title":"Cable fault location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_fault_location"},{"title":"Receiver autonomous integrity monitoring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver_autonomous_integrity_monitoring"},{"title":"Brake fluid pressure sensor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brake_fluid_pressure_sensor"},{"title":"Memory tester - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_tester"},{"title":"Buchholz relay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buchholz_relay"}]

Here are the search results for "Fault detection":

## Overview

Fault detection, isolation, and recovery (FDIR) is a subfield of control engineering which concerns itself with monitoring a system, identifying when a fault has occurred, and pinpointing the type of fault and its location.

## Approaches

Two approaches can be distinguished: a direct pattern recognition of sensor readings that indicate a fault and an analysis of the discrepancy between the sensor readings and expected values, derived from some model.

## Techniques

Fault detection and isolation (FDI) techniques can be broadly classified into two categories, which include model-based FDI and signal processing based FDI.

- **Model-based FDI**: In model-based FDI techniques some model of the system is used to decide about the occurrence of fault.

- **Signal processing-based FDI**: In signal processing based FDI, some mathematical or statistical operations are performed on the measurements, or some neural network is trained using measurements to extract the information about the fault.

## Common Detection Methods

The most common technique for detecting faults is the time-frequency analysis technique.

The search results also include specific applications of fault detection in electrical systems (arc-fault detection), GPS systems (RAIM), cable fault location, and various industrial equipment monitoring systems.

Web search results for query: "Kalman filter"

Links: [{"title":"Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Extended Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Fast Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Invariant extended Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_extended_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Talk:Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Talk:Fast Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fast_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Ensemble Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Switching Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switching_Kalman_filter"},{"title":"Kalman–Bucy filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Kalman%E2%80%93Bucy_filter&redirect=no"},{"title":"File:Kalman filter model.png","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Kalman_filter_model.png"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of the Kalman filter:

## Definition and Purpose

The Kalman filter is an algorithm that uses a series of measurements observed over time, including statistical noise and other inaccuracies, to produce estimates of unknown variables that tend to be more accurate than those based on a single measurement, by estimating a joint probability distribution over the variables for each time-step.(no content)The filter is named after Rudolf E. Kálmán.

## How It Works

The algorithm works via a two-phase process: a prediction phase and an update phase. In the prediction phase, the Kalman filter produces estimates of the current state variables, including their uncertainties. Once the outcome of the next measurement is observed, these estimates are updated using a weighted average, with more weight given to estimates with greater certainty.

## Applications

A common application is for guidance, navigation, and control of vehicles, particularly aircraft, spacecraft and ships positioned dynamically.(no content)Kalman filtering is much applied in time series analysis tasks such as signal processing and econometrics.(no content)Kalman filtering is also important for robotic motion planning and control, and can be used for trajectory optimization.

## Variants

Extensions and generalizations of the method have also been developed, such as the extended Kalman filter and the unscented Kalman filter which work on nonlinear systems.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of the Kalman filter:

## Definition and Purpose

The Kalman filter is an algorithm that uses a series of measurements observed over time, including statistical noise and other inaccuracies, to produce estimates of unknown variables that tend to be more accurate than those based on a single measurement, by estimating a joint probability distribution over the variables for each time-step.(no content)The filter is named after Rudolf E. Kálmán.

## How It Works

The algorithm works via a two-phase process: a prediction phase and an update phase. In the prediction phase, the Kalman filter produces estimates of the current state variables, including their uncertainties. Once the outcome of the next measurement is observed, these estimates are updated using a weighted average, with more weight given to estimates with greater certainty.

## Applications

A common application is for guidance, navigation, and control of vehicles, particularly aircraft, spacecraft and ships positioned dynamically.(no content)Kalman filtering is much applied in time series analysis tasks such as signal processing and econometrics.(no content)Kalman filtering is also important for robotic motion planning and control, and can be used for trajectory optimization.

## Variants

Extensions and generalizations of the method have also been developed, such as the extended Kalman filter and the unscented Kalman filter which work on nonlinear systems.

Web search results for query: "Stability theory"

Links: [{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Stable theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_theory"},{"title":"Hegemonic stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hegemonic_stability_theory"},{"title":"Stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability"},{"title":"Stability (learning theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_(learning_theory)"},{"title":"Category:Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Stability_theory"},{"title":"Stability (probability) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_(probability)"},{"title":"Stability spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_spectrum"},{"title":"Stability–instability paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability–instability_paradox"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"}]

Here are the search results for "Stability theory":

## Main Overview

In mathematics, stability theory addresses the stability of solutions of differential equations and of trajectories of dynamical systems under small perturbations of initial conditions.

## Key Concepts

Stability theory addresses the following questions: Will a nearby orbit indefinitely stay close to a given orbit? Will it converge to the given orbit?(no content)One of the key ideas in stability theory is that the qualitative behavior of an orbit under perturbations can be analyzed using the linearization of the system near the orbit.

## Analysis Methods

The stability of a linear system can be determined by solving the differential equation to find the eigenvalues, or without solving the equation by using the Routh–Hurwitz stability criterion.(no content)A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.

## Related Variations

There are several related fields that use "stability theory" terminology:

- **Stable Theory (Model Theory)**: In the mathematical field of model theory, a theory is called stable if it satisfies certain combinatorial restrictions on its complexity.

- **Algorithmic Stability**: Stability, also known as algorithmic stability, is a notion in computational learning theory of how a machine learning algorithm output is changed with small perturbations to its inputs. A stable learning algorithm is one for which the prediction does not change much when the training data is modified slightly.

Web search results for query: "Robust control"

Links: [{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Nichols plot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nichols_plot"},{"title":"Minor loop feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_loop_feedback"},{"title":"Keith Glover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keith_Glover"},{"title":"Power to the edge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_to_the_edge_(management_technique)"},{"title":"Youla–Kucera parametrization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youla–Kucera_parametrization"},{"title":"Innovative Vector Control Consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovative_Vector_Control_Consortium"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of robust control:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.(no content)The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.

## Key Characteristics

Tolerance to modeling uncertainty is an essential part of any feedback control scheme, that is, the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design.(no content)A controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

## Types of Uncertainty

Robust control addresses two main types of uncertainty:

- Parametric uncertainty refers to the case where modeling parameters or external disturbances in feedback regulation are expected to be found within some (typically compact) set of a finite dimensional space.
- Non-parametric uncertainty refers to the case where the magnitude of expected modeling errors and disturbances is quantified via metrics on function spaces where these reside (infinite dimensional).

## H-Infinity Control

The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.(no content)H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance. To use H∞ methods, a control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control systems:

## General Definition

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems.

## Types of Control Systems

### Open-Loop vs. Closed-Loop
A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)Open-loop control systems do not make use of feedback, and run only in pre-arranged ways.

### On-Off Control
On–off control uses a feedback controller that switches abruptly between two states. A simple bi-metallic domestic thermostat can be described as an on-off controller.

### Industrial Control Systems
An industrial control system (ICS) is an electronic control system and associated instrumentation used for industrial process control.(no content)Control systems can range in size from a few modular panel-mounted controllers to large interconnected and interactive distributed control systems (DCSs) with many thousands of field connections.

### Distributed Control Systems
Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.

## Real-World Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** This is a **survey** paper, as it reviews existing literature on communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis in networked systems without proposing new methods.

**Extracted Key Technologies & Methodologies (7 triples):**

1. **Communication Protocol** (concept) - Central to the survey's focus on protocol-based analysis
2. **Networked Control System** (concept) - The main subject area dealing with control loops through communication networks
3. **Control System** (concept) - Provides the theoretical foundation for control problems
4. **Kalman Filter** (method) - Key technique for filtering and state estimation in networked systems
5. **Stability Theory** (concept) - Critical for analyzing stability under protocol scheduling
6. **Fault Detection and Isolation** (method) - Major topic in communication-protocol-based fault diagnosis
7. **Robust Control** (method) - Addresses parameter uncertainties in networked systems

All triples have been validated with Wikipedia links and relevance descriptions. The validation script confirmed:
- ✅ All 7 triples properly documented
- ✅ Correct entity types: 4 concepts, 3 methods
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs are valid
- ✅ Paper type correctly classified as "survey"

The output file (`triples_output.json`) is ready and validated.

Sources:
- [Communication protocol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_protocol)
- [Networked control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system)
- [Control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system)
- [Kalman filter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter)
- [Stability theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory)
- [Fault detection and isolation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation)
- [Robust control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control)
